name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on the situation in Hong Kong (2019/2732(RSP)).

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: author. – Madam President, the Groups of this Parliament have come together to move a joint resolution on human rights breaches in Hong Kong. I think this is a symbolically highly relevant action by this new Parliament because we have always held that EU foreign policy would be based on the fundamental values that our Union stands for: human rights, the rule of law and democracy. When we see people rising in defence of their civic and human rights, we as Europeans must express our solidarity and this is what we do with the people of Hong Kong through this resolution.  (Applause)

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: author. – Madam President, the people of Hong Kong are afraid. This fear is to be detected easily everywhere. They protest continually. The reason for their fear is the imposing of the extradition bill and they think that the concept of one state, two systems may lead eventually to their oppression and intimidation. I’m afraid that these protests will continue unless the situation is solved politically, which is what we appeal for.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: author. – Madam President, the proposed extrajudicial law that would make it easier to extradite people from Hong Kong to China has triggered over recent weeks a most massive protest in Hong Kong’s history. This is not the way a country’s two-system principle should work in practice. We support a call for the full withdrawal of this law. The Hong Kong Government should immediately release, and drop all charges against, the peaceful protesters and all those detained during or before the protests for the peaceful exercise of their freedom of expression. Hong Kong’s legislation of should remain fully in line with its international and human rights obligations. In its ongoing reform process and increasing global engagement, China has opted into the international human rights framework by signing up to a wide range of international human rights treaties. Therefore, we have to pursue dialogue with China to encourage it to live up to these commitments.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Author. – Madam President, we support the right of expression in all parts of the world, as a fundamental right. Also in the case of Hong Kong, where they manifest themselves to request the withdrawal of the extradition law. As in all parts of the world, we also call for an investigation into police action and call for the release of peaceful protesters. But we also want to denounce the hypocrisy of the European Union, which only sees human rights violations outside its borders and which looks the other way when they are also violated in Europe. Similarly, we call for a dialogue between the institutions of the European Union and China, to guarantee the rights of people in Hong Kong, as well as to establish a European stance with China adapted to the geopolitical challenges of the 21st century, where human rights, respect for the environment and labour rights are a fundamental element of our future relationship with China.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: Author. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Hong Kong's ongoing peaceful demonstrations are among the largest since Hong Kong joined China in 1997. I therefore agree that the suspension of work on them alone is not sufficient and that this project should be formally withdrawn. It is also necessary to release the demonstrators who expressed their concern about the changes carried out without delay. I are also concerned about freedom of expression and the press, including the pressure on journalists and self-censorship of speech about China and the government. I would like to stress that freedom of expression is a fundamental human right and that respect for it is fundamental.

name: Antony HOOK
text: author. – Madam President, we should all be proud of this resolution that has the support of the five largest Groups in our European Parliament. This is important because Europe – our 28 states – is strongest when we are united. We share an unshakable commitment to democracy and human rights, not just for ourselves but for every person on this planet. For weeks now, up to two million people in Hong Kong have protested on their streets, protests against an extradition bill brought by the Hong Kong Government, which is not elected by its people, which would see people rendered to mainland China where, according to countless NGO reports, torture, unfair trials and forced confessions are endemic. This  is entirely at odds with the reassurances that were given to the Hong Kong people when that territory was transferred in 1997. Police have met these protests with force and violence that is unnecessary and it must be clear that here in Europe we support Hong Kong protesters.  We support their call for the Government to fully withdraw the bill and for an independent inquiry into the police’s actions. We call for free and fair elections. We say to the people of Hong Kong that the people of Europe stand with you. We say to the Governments of Hong Kong and China that we implore you to respect the dignity and the rights of every single individual and then together we can build a world of peace and justice for everyone.  (Applause)

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, having visited Hong Kong and being a guest in particular of the Jockey Club, I saw what a wonderful, vibrant, sporting city it is and how the people enjoy their freedom and peace. That’s now being threatened and I think it is absolutely wonderful that the European Parliament in its first official session on this urgent topic urgencies are highlighting the issues in Hong Kong. It’s not right that people should be detained for exercising their right to free expression. It’s not right that people should be detained for trying to promote their own civil rights, political rights and press freedom, and it is absolutely right that the European Union, working with the international community, should put pressure on China and Hong Kong to ensure that these violations of human rights will stop. I think we’ll have to be very vigilant over the next number of years to show that, number one, we stand by Hong Kong and, two, that we are against human rights violations anywhere in the world.

name: Neena GILL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the protests we’ve seen in the past weeks in Hong Kong are a really encouraging sign that the people of Hong Kong will not let their freedoms be abolished. The sheer scale is unprecedented, and the outcome of this crisis will be a turning point for Hong Kong’s position in China. If the protesters prevail, this will be a big win for freedom in Hong Kong. However, if Beijing wins, this will be a premature end to ‘one country, two systems’. You can rest assured that we will then see very many people being brought to trial under less than ideal conditions. So, the European Union must take a clear stance and support the freedoms in Hong Kong. It’s really important that China is in global focus at the moment, with what’s going on in Hong Kong and its economy is slowing down, and what’s going on in Xinjiang. It’s really important, in the summits and the meetings that we have with China, that we stress the human rights issue. It’s really important that the High Representative – the current one and the incoming one – take this issue up.

name: Jordan BARDELLA
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, if we of course want the situation in Hong Kong to calm down as soon as possible, we can deplore the propensity of the European Parliament to see itself as the United Nations in order to impose its views on the whole world. The movement that rose in Hong Kong began with a claim of national sovereignty against Beijing. It then expanded by demanding more democracy and freedom, national sovereignty, democracy and freedom of expression. The European Union has, at the moment, no lessons to be taught in these areas. The role of the European Union should be, first and foremost, to defend the common interests of our nations. What is the European Union doing about the total lack of reciprocity between China and Europe on investment and trade? What is the European Union doing to meet the great challenges of the century such as digital and artificial intelligence, which are now heavily invested by China? What is the European Union doing about the threat to our food sovereignty posed by the grabbing of French agricultural land by Chinese companies? What is the European Union doing to protect our vineyards, our industries, our infrastructure, such as airports, on which Chinese funds are often linked to Beijing's power? Before we get involved in what China is doing in Hong Kong, let us use common sense and first worry about what China is doing in Europe.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I congratulate you on your first plenary speech and wish you good luck in your capacity. Let me also join the resolution that we are voting on today. I would like to point out that Parliament's position here is continuous. In the last parliamentary term, we dealt with the case of two booksellers who were kidnapped from Hong Kong to China and imprisoned there and subjected to a legal process that was contrary to the basic principles of a fair trial. So there is a real fear that China would abuse such a law, that people suspected of political offenses would be issued to China in this way, and that they would be punished there in violation of the principles of criminal law. So we support the people of Hong Kong here. It is good that we are on their side and let us do everything we can to ensure that this law is eventually completely withdrawn, not just suspended, which is the current situation that logically does not suit the people of Hong Kong.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, of course, human rights, we have discussed them and we are discussing them in the European Parliament. We must have respect for human rights all over the world. Obviously, we are mainly interested in the European Union, but also in the third countries with which the European Union has relations.  It is a resolution that we sign. The problem that I raise here, are we credible in the request of other Member States, when within the European Union we have situations of non-compliance with human rights? Obviously we don't want Hong Kong citizens to suffer, we don't want Chinese citizens to suffer. We want human rights to be respected. However, the problem that we have to solve here is to be a good example of us, first, and then to teach others.

name: Phil BENNION
text: – Madam President, the proposed Extradition Act represents an assault on the ‘one country, two systems’ principle, which was set up all those years ago to protect the human rights and autonomy of the people of Hong Kong. But above that, it is actually helpful to China too, and if China is putting pressure on the Hong Kong Government to bring this act into place it is not acting in its own interests. China sources the capital it needs for economic growth – which brings prosperity to its very poor people – through the financial sector in Hong Kong, and we’re already seeing some of the jobs there fleeing to other centres around Asia. As China is so dependent on Hong Kong for its prosperity, it really should be putting pressure on the government of Hong Kong to withdraw this act, and not putting pressure on them to get this act through their legislature.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, you know well that the European Union is closely following the situation in Hong Kong. In recent weeks, we have seen the people of Hong Kong marching in unprecedented numbers, exercising their fundamental rights of freedom of expression and assembly, as guaranteed by the Basic Law. The massive demonstrations over the last weeks have shown the determination of the Hong Kong people to keep the ‘one country, two systems’ principle intact.  I would like to take this opportunity of the debate today to recall that the EU’s full support for the ‘one country, two systems’ principle and its implementation remains very vocal. The principle gives Hong Kong a high degree of autonomy and ensures respect for the fundamental rights and freedoms of Hong Kong’s people.  This principle is also key for business confidence in Hong Kong. Hong Kong, as you know and as you have already said, is an important financial centre, a global hub for offshore Renminbi (RMB) business and a strategic trans-shipment port. The ‘one country, two systems’ principle is essential for Hong Kong to continue to fully play its strategic economic role. Since the beginning of the movement, the European Union has called for restraint by all sides, underlining that violence and escalatory responses must be avoided. We reject all kinds of violence. We were deeply shocked by the events of 1 July at the Legislative Council building.  The European Union shares many of the concerns raised by citizens of Hong Kong regarding the government’s proposed extradition reforms. This is a very sensitive issue with potentially far-reaching consequences for Hong Kong and its people, for the European Union and foreign citizens, as well as for business confidence in Hong Kong. The Government has said that it will no longer pursue the controversial bill, but the tensions persist.  We witness with concern that the trust between society, especially the young generation, in Hong Kong and the government, is more and more fragile. More protests have been announced. It is really more vital than ever to engage in dialogue to bridge the tensions within society for the benefit of the Hong Kong people at large and the Special Administrative Region’s (SAR) standing as an international hub.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The debate is closed. The vote will be held at the end of the debates.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the situation at the USA-Mexican border (2019/2733(RSP)).

name: Tineke STRIK
text: author. – Madam President, pushback policies towards migrants at the border are an increasing tendency all over the world. They are a grave violation of the Refugee Convention as they deprive migrants of the right to seek asylum and get protection if they are in need of this. The results are painfully visible in the Mexican-US border region, and this resolution therefore urges both countries to live up to their international obligations. Trump’s policy is shamelessly violating international law by separating children from their parents and even detaining them, by detaining many migrants in appalling circumstances and by sending asylum seekers back to Mexican cities. Back in Mexico they struggle to get access to an asylum procedure, and if they manage to lodge an asylum claim, the lengthy procedure is unclear and lacks the normal safeguards. As asylum seekers don’t have access to shelter or other basic needs, they are extremely vulnerable to exploitation and violence. The US Government refuses to take any responsibility and is forcing Mexico to deal with the migrants and refugees. In autumn last year most countries ratified the UN Global Compact on Refugees, in which almost all countries promised to share responsibility for refugees. Pushback actions go totally against this common objective and they also trigger the same policies in other countries. If there’s no common responsibility, no one wants to take it up. The USA did not sign this compact but it still has to comply with its international obligations. It is therefore crucial that our Parliament does not accept these violations and that it urges a halt to these practices and calls for human rights to be respected.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: Author. – Madam President, good morning to all; every government has the right and obligation to defend its borders, domestic legality and sovereignty. This is a key point that concerns both the United States of America and Mexico, as well as European countries. We are witnessing a permanent turmoil in which the U.S. government is virtually obliged to renounce all three: to defend its borders, to defend its sovereignty, and to defend its legality. That can't be. Actually, we have seen coordination and turmoil, from within and outside the United States, to violate that border, to encourage entire columns, organized from the outside, to attack that border and to violate it, which are unprecedented and deserve our condemnation. The right of asylum has to be guaranteed and the situation on the Mexican border with the United States has to be regulated, and at many other borders as well. But Mexico has also recognized, as other countries recognize, that the United States is making efforts to regulate that, and that it really has to approve and understand that the alarming situation on the U.S. border depends much more on the aggression that is taking place than on America's legitimate right to defend its border and sovereignty.

name: Nacho SÁNCHEZ AMOR
text: Author. – Madam President, first of all, it must be regretted that, after almost four hours of negotiation and a formal commitment by the EPP to sign this resolution, a few minutes before its registration, the EPP communicated its refusal. It is obvious that the staging of the negotiation was only intended to reduce as much as possible the critical tone of the text, and we note this strategy. There are a huge number of aspects of America's current immigration policy that would merit harsh criticism, both politically and ethically. I will cite only two: the deliberate use of family separation as a mechanism to discourage crossings, their use as a conscious deterrent — not as a necessity for any other reason — and the subsequent overcrowding of all people in those centres without any conditions. And a second aspect: the use of the threat of a trade war, of a tariff war, to force changes in the migration policy of a neighboring and supposedly allied country. Since we are allies of the United States, we must show our deep rejection of these practices. I believe vice president Mike Pence will be haunted all his life by the ominous picture of his walk next to caged people asking for a dignified treatment; a photo too similar to some photographs of Europe that we don't want to see repeated anywhere in the world.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Author. " Madam President, lately, Trump has been insulting Democratic MEPs with racist and sexist statements; a smokescreen to cover up his new immigration plan that promotes tougher border controls and further restricts conditions for asylum. It does so just after it has announced xenophobic raids to stop people who have fled misery and violence, coups and corrupt governments, such as Honduras, who are supported by the United States and Europe. Addressing human mobility from a repressive approach promotes xenophobia, hatred and violence. We denounce the criminalization of solidarity, the populism of the walls, the outsourcing of borders, racist raids, mass and illegal returns and the inhumane family separation, for which minors are being imprisoned, separating them from their mothers and their parents, just for emigrating. We also join the democratic congressmen's request for the closure of detention centres, because migrating is not a crime. The borders of the United States and Europe are now the most dangerous in the world. And, what a coincidence, on one side the far right rules, and on the other it is the right and the far right that set the migration agenda. Let's take responsibility. Let's stop looking the other way and uttering nice words that don't translate into facts, because otherwise people will continue to die on the other side of our door.

name: Isabel WISELER-LIMA
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the influx of asylum seekers but also illegal migrants is a real challenge, both for the United States and, for that matter, for Europe. Reports by the US administration itself note that the saturation situation at various reception centres at the US-Mexico border has become dangerous and that immediate action is needed. Moreover, the separation of children from their parents is particularly deplorable, if not unacceptable. On the Mexican side, trained agents, not the military, should deal with migrants. On the other hand, major actions should be taken to prevent migrants crossing Mexico into the US from being victims of all kinds of violence and human trafficking. We therefore consider the situation to be very worrying. However, the EPP does not support this motion in its entirety, it considers that the text does not present the responsibilities of the two countries in a balanced manner and does not sufficiently take into account the political situation in that region. Moreover, the United States is a state of law, a partner country with which there are other forms and means of dealing with our disputes.

name: Sheila RITCHIE
text: author. – Madam President, I was asked by my constituent, Jody Rae from Edinburgh, to raise this matter and I’m proud to do so. Can I ask Members to cast their minds back for a few seconds to when they were children? Most of us will have had a warm, loving and safe childhood. Contrast that with the childhood of the children that we are talking about today. They were brought up surrounded by men with guns, by illness, hunger, dirt, poverty and fear, so bad that their parents took them on a perilous journey in pursuit of life, liberty and happiness, as guaranteed under the United States Declaration of Independence. Then they found themselves in detention camps, surrounded by men with guns, by illness, hunger, dirt, poverty and fear. The United States of America, one of the richest countries in the world, does not have to do this. It is the only country in the world that has not ratified the Convention on the Rights of the Child. Mr Trump, give these children a present for the 30th anniversary of the Convention: sign it!

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The fact that we, as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, have presented our own text on the subject is due to the fact that we also see the migration problem in America, but we take a more nuanced view than other groups in the House. There is a great deal of unease in our group about addressing our important partner, the United States, with the instrument of the emergency resolution on cases of violations of human rights, the rule of law and democracy. Our House has other instruments for this: for example, in the Transatlantic Dialogue between legislators or in the US delegation, the detailed and trusting discussion with our American friends could be held. We in the EU and in the Member States do not agree on the handling of migration itself and are not free of mistakes. It is therefore not a good thing for us to criticise our closest international partner in this form at the beginning of this new Parliament. We ourselves in the specialist committees have not yet taken the necessary time to find common positions on difficult issues. That is why we will not be able to vote in favour of this resolution as a result.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the United States is facing an unprecedented migration crisis. A total of 700 000 migrants have been apprehended since October 2018 and more than 12 000 unaccompanied children were detained in May only. At least 197 people died trying to cross the US-Mexican border this year alone, and the Trump administration is responding to this crisis with violent push-backs of asylum seekers, indefinite detention of migrants, denying them the most basic needs, and the traumatising separation of children from their families. And just this week, U.S. Immigration Customs and Enforcement started large-scale raids on undocumented migrants. As a European, I know very well that migration is a global phenomena and the EU and the US share the very same challenges at their borders, but it is also up to both sides of the Atlantic to bear collective responsibility and to show a dignified way forward. And to Mr Gahler, just a reaction to his speech – I understand the position of the EPP but perhaps it’s better not to first spend four hours negotiating a joint text and then pull back three minutes before the deadline. (Applause)

name: Karen MELCHIOR
text: renew group. Madam President! The individual never has to deal with another human being without holding some of his life in his hand. Those words come from K.E. Løgstrup, a Danish theologian and philosopher of religion. Løgstrup was preoccupied with finding a universal basis for ethics, a proper way of treating each other.  It sounds simple, but the reality is different. The refugees and migrants detained at the US-Mexican border are not being treated properly. On the contrary, they are being detained in cruel conditions. Cruel, especially to children who are separated from their parents and do not have access to water, food and medical care. We simply cannot accept that.  When we detain, incarcerate or otherwise restrict people's freedom through our migration and refugee policy, we assume enormous responsibility. We literally hold the lives of these people in our hands. We must take that responsibility more seriously here in Europe, as must the United States. This is an urgent matter.  With our friends, we have to be able to be most honest. That is why the United States must immediately start the reunification of these children with their families, and the United States must ensure full reunification with the children and their families so that they can celebrate Christmas together this year.

name: Susanna CECCARDI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the resolution before this House today condemns the treatment of illegal immigrants in the USA, particularly minors, as if we were talking about a third world country.  In America, the policy of separating minors accompanied by legal immigrant adults is nothing new. There is a judgment, Flores v. Reno – a case of mistreatment suffered in an CIE by a 15-year-old Salvadoran woman, dating back to 1997 – according to which children cannot be detained in CIEs together with adults awaiting sentencing. The Trump administration, therefore, did not change the rules, they were the same rules even under Democratic governments. Children are being held in other NGO-controlled facilities. In the New York Times, illegal immigrants admitted that they had brought children with them, believing that in this way the US authorities would release them. Others admitted that the children who were with them were not their children. Policies to curb illegal immigration are sacrosanct. Those who build a fence around their home do not do it because they hate those outside, but to protect those inside. President Trump's clarity in the unreserved fight against illegal immigration is certainly preferable to the buonism to which European leaders accustomed us years ago, who claimed, in words, to open their doors and hearts to all immigrants and then dumped the problem on the countries of first reception. This Parliament is primarily concerned with taking an interest in the defence of Europe's borders rather than trying to give humanitarian and civil lessons to the United States of America.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, we are talking here about the southern border of the United States. We could also talk about europe's southern border. But I don't hear about that at all! So there is no reason for moral pride or condemnation of the United States.  More than 3,000 migrants drowned in the Mediterranean in 2017. On the U.S. southern border, far fewer people have drowned in the Rio Grande and about 400 people have died. The problem in Europe is therefore much bigger than in the United States, but we condemn the United States! Let's look at our own house first. A migration policy cannot be done without effective borders. Only at effective limits can you tell who can get in, what criteria there are, who doesn't get in, where work needs to be found. You can negotiate with other countries, countries of origin, countries of transit, and so on. But if we don't have that, we get mass immigration, we get more and more people, and as a result, tensions in big cities in Europe. And we shouldn't have that. So instead of seeing the splinter in the eye of the United States, ladies and gentlemen members of the European Parliament and the European Commission, you should look at the beam in your own eye.

name: Manu PINEDA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, death of minors in detention centres, de facto prisons where the most basic human rights of migrants are not respected, where they are denied the right to asylum and the principle of non-re-reversing is violated, in contravenment of international law. We know that this terrible situation is happening on the border of the United States and Mexico, but also in the European Union itself. Trump's racist policies have led to the deaths of 400 people in the past year. In the Mediterranean drowned 2,200 by the fortress Europe. Not only do we copy Trump's immigration policies, but we overcome them. Border closures, walls of shame and CIDs are one of the biggest scandals of this century and for which the European Union will be held accountable. This whole strategy fuels criminal business. The priority should be to save lives at sea and at borders, but also to fight the causes of migration: not to provoke or support wars, not to expose their natural resources, and to fight climate change that forces them to flee their peoples.

name: Ioannis LAGOS
text: Madam President, I find the debate that is taking place very hypocritical and I cannot understand how we can reprimand countries that close their borders and do not allow illegal immigrants to pass through their countries, but we do not rebuke the countries that lead to this situation. So if some should be punished, it is they who lead the citizens of their countries to be led into these situations. That is the one thing. Secondly, I hear a lot about humanism. I hear and play too much of this conversation, but humanism is always for all illegal immigrants, who cross the border with it that I want.  Have we really ever thought and spoken in humanitarian terms about what our fellow Europeans are experiencing from all these hordes of illegal immigrants? Have we ever discussed what these people have suffered? I'm from Greece. We have experienced this whole wave of illegal immigration very well. Do you know how many people have been killed? Do you know how many rapes and robberies have taken place? So for these people, I have not heard many of you talk about humanism, have I not seen us want to help them and finally see those who trample on rights are those who smuggle themselves through our borders or those who normally experience in the countries of their ancestors?

name: Maria ARENA
text: Madam President, last year we celebrated the 70th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. And yet, all over the world, we are seeing a clear decline in respect for these rights. Never before have human rights been so at the heart of current events on the continents that once carried these universal values. Is it necessary to recall that one of the founding texts of the United States is the Bill of Rights? Yet today, 3,000 families have been forcibly separated at the Mexican border, due to a radical, anti-migrant policy led by the Trump administration. Mental health professionals have warned that the separation and conditions of juvenile detention will undoubtedly result in immediate and lasting trauma. Colleagues, a child is first and foremost a child. This is the starting point for any discussion of the rights of migrant children. Enforcing the best interests of the child, as the first consideration to be taken into account at all stages of the migration process, must be the priority there, here in Europe as well. In conclusion, I will quote Eleanor Roosevelt who said: "Where do human rights begin? Where men, women and children seek justice, equal dignity, without discrimination." If we do not defend them near us, we will seek only in vain progress in the rest of the world.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, cinnte is ceart droch-chleachtadh ag daoine i Meiriceá maidir le leanaí a scagadh óna dtuismitheoirí a cháineadh. Is droch-chleachtadh amach is amach é agus déanann sé an-díobháil do leanaí go háirithe. Ach ag an am céanna, sa tuarascáil seo, táimid ag cáineadh rudaí, go háirithe maidir le hiompar fhórsaí na Stáit Aontaithe le teifigh ag an teorainn, gur féidir an rud céanna a rá faoinár dteorainn féin. Agus ní bheimis róshásta dá mbeadh tuarascáil i dTeach na nIonadaithe ag cáineadh an Aontais. Dá bhrí sin, nuair a bhíonn gach rud curtha i gceart againn, in ord is in eagar, ar imircigh agus teifigh ag ár dteorainn féin, is féidir linn ansin tíortha eile a cháineadh. Go raibh maith agat.

name: Jackie JONES
text: – Madam President, the situation on the US-Mexico border is growing more severe by the day, as the US Government fails to have any action to adequately protect vulnerable migrants and it is separating families fleeing from political turmoil and conflict in Latin America.  Women and girls are especially vulnerable, and there is evidence of widespread sexual abuse and harassment at detention centres by US border and government staff. This situation is racialised and gendered. The President’s remarks this week, and at the rally last night, telling four Congresswomen to go back to the places where they came from, must be condemned in the strongest terms. We are not only witnessing a backlash against women’s rights with these attacks, and also against migrants and refugees, but also an attack on human rights in general and those who defend them. We must send a clear message that racist and sexist violations of human rights and the attacks on those defending them have no place in any modern democracy.

name: Irina VON WIESE
text: – Madam President, I am a child and grandchild of refugees, so it pains me deeply to watch the horrors that the migrants and refugees are undergoing in American border camps. The United States have long been the defender of human rights. This is the country that saved millions of Europeans in two world wars; the country that founded the United Nations. Their proud history is being tarnished by this shameful episode.  This is not just about the families who fled violence and abuse, only to be met with more violence and abuse; this is also about the European Union’s credibility. How can we call on others to uphold human rights if we refuse to condemn the failings of our own allies? We must tell America: close the camps!

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, we are following with great attention the unfolding situation of migrants across the Central American region. Thousands aim to cross the US-Mexico border in the hope of reaching safety and building a livelihood for themselves, their families and their children. The reasons are manifold and many were noted in the earlier debate of the previous European Parliament on 14 November 2018.  While the situation on the ground requires urgent responses by the relevant authorities, the root causes of the migratory flows that drive many to the US’s southern borders have long been present. Only a persistent, systematic and coordinated joint effort by the countries concerned in the international community may lead to an improvement on the ground. The European Union is concerned by reports about the current situation in the border areas. The separation of families of migrants, the cases of ill—treatment of migrants, and of course the conditions in detention centres, as you have already emphasised.  The European Union continues to stand firmly on the side of human dignity. We reiterate the importance of protecting human rights and respecting international law, while we also recall the right of each country to manage its borders.  The European Union’s policy aims to promote regular and well-managed migration while addressing the root causes of irregular migration, enforced displacement and of course fighting human trafficking and smuggling. As the European Union, we have undertaken a strong effort in supporting the countries in the region, based on the principle of partnership and international cooperation in addressing migratory cooperation and challenges. Our policy builds on a comprehensive approach, which includes, first of all, saving lives, and secondly, ensuring protection and support, as well as legal pathways for those in need of international protection. The European Union’s long-standing cooperation efforts towards the countries of the so-called ‘northern triangle’ – Honduras, Guatemala, El Salvador – are in fact addressing the main drivers of migration. European Union cooperation has been strengthening the rule of law and fighting crime and gang violence, but also violence against women and vulnerable groups such as LGBTI or indigenous people. European Union funds have been provided to address the dire consequences of climate change, in particular in terms of food security, and to promote the creation of jobs, along with the opening of our markets.  In addition, in line with what we commit to do with our Mexican counterparts under the modernised EU-Mexico Association Agreement, we invite the US and Mexico to cooperate on migration issues to foster safe, regular and orderly migration to prevent irregular migration, to counter migrant smuggling and trafficking in persons. We also call for the protection of migrant women and children, particularly those who are unaccompanied, as well as other vulnerable groups.  As the European Union, we stand ready to work together with the countries concerned – the US, Mexico and Central American countries – in addressing this issue. In this respect, we support the El Salvador-Guatemala-Honduras-Mexico Comprehensive Development Plan, as proposed by the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean, currently being developed and discussed with partners in the region which, as you know, aims at addressing the root causes of irregular migration.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The debate is closed. The vote will be held at the end of the debates.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: I have been informed that a delegation led by Mr Petro Poroshenko, former President of Ukraine, is present in the diplomatic gallery to attend today’s debate and the vote. On behalf of the European Parliament, I would like to welcome you here, and wish you fruitful discussions, meetings, and a nice day in Strasbourg. (Applause)

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Russia, notably the situation of environmental activists and Ukrainian political prisoners (2019/2734(RSP)).

name: Catherine ROWETT
text: author. – Madam President, throughout this week speakers have affirmed our European commitment to the highest democratic principles. And after all, it’s only after trying our hardest to live up to those principles in this House that we earn the right to criticise others. Now, however, we must stand up with equal passion for our sisters and brothers elsewhere who face much greater threats to their democratic rights. And most of all, we must cry out against the oppression of well-intentioned people protesting against environmental crimes, for it is they, not those who suppress them, who correctly discern which are the greatest threats to peace and survival. I invite you, colleagues, to join me in condemning the actions of the Russian authorities against these activists and organisations. Their plight is our plight, and their campaign for a clean place to live is a campaign for our world too. These voices must not be silenced. (Applause)

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: author. – Madam President, I note with satisfaction the fact that we in this Parliament remain in the lead in a balanced and realistic assessment of Russia’s human rights policies vis—à-vis both its own people and other nations and ethnic groups. The situation became particularly grave after the illegal annexation of Crimea and aggression in eastern Ukraine. We are aware that the Ukrainian people monitor our proceedings closely. This debate affects their attitude towards the European Union. It is important that the distinguished spectators are also in our gallery. We remain outspoken. The resolution contains in footnotes the verified list of political prisoners. We appeal for their immediate release and we condemn these actions of oppression against the nation.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: Author. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the resolution we are now discussing represents a clear position in the name of defending human rights and the principles of democracy and the rule of law and condemning its repeated violation by the authorities of the Russian Federation. We condemn the arbitrariness committed by Russia in the detention of Ukrainian citizens on Russian territory and in the temporarily occupied territories of Ukraine and call for the swift and unconditional release of Tatar activists, Ukrainians detained on politically motivated charges and the 24 sailors captured in the Kerch Strait. We denounce the attacks on freedom of association and expression that civil society has been targeted by, notably through the law that leads to the classification of some NGOs as foreign agents, and we strongly condemn the persecutory acts that have been targeted by environmental activists. We call for these detainees to be released quickly, for disproportionate force to cease to be used against peaceful demonstrators and for the Russian Federation to swiftly return to compliance with the principles of the rule of law and respect for human rights.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: author. – Madam President, the situation of human rights in the Russian occupied territories of Crimea and eastern Ukraine continues to raise our deep concern and outrage. We shed a light on the fate of prisoners that have protested against this occupation, be they ethnic Ukrainians, Russians or Tatars. Inside Russia, civil society activists in different areas of society continue to be harassed, including environmental activists. We therefore call on the Russian authorities to release, without further delay and unconditionally, all illegally and arbitrarily detained Ukrainian citizens, both in Russia and in the temporarily occupied territories of Ukraine, and to provide for their safe return, including Crimean Tatars and the recently detained Red Square peaceful demonstrators of 10 July, Ukrainian citizens detained under politically motivated charges and the 24 crew members of the Ukrainian naval vessel. We urge the Russian authorities to stop curtailing peaceful and legitimate activities of environmental organisations by fabricating criminal cases against local environmental activists, arresting participants of local peaceful protests or imposing disproportionately heavy fines on them. (Applause)

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: Author. – Madam President, Putin does not respect human rights. Last Sunday, dozens of people were arrested again in Moscow during a spontaneous protest against the political monopoly. Civil society is systematically repressed and harassed with Soviet tools such as the Foreign Agents Act, which ranks NGOs in a public register of infamousness, and then penalizes them financially and even criminally. Abuse, violence, political arrests, torture. This is what the Kremlin does, not only with its own citizens, but also with Ukrainian activists, minority representatives or the free press. In the full defiance of international law, Ukrainian citizens were captured, detained in terrible circumstances and subjected to torture.  Putin's Russia cannot be a partner for the European Union, as long as it brutally violates human rights and international law. Yesterday was the 5th anniversary of the MH17 tragedy. 298 people died. Putin takes zero responsibility for these lives. Respect for human rights must be the core of the negotiation in all the European Union's contacts with Russia, including economic agreements. We urgently need a Magnistky law at European level to punish all those who violate human rights. If there are no real consequences for Russian officials, the Kremlin will continue to behave with contempt and total impunity - "Welcome, Ukraine, we are with you!"

name: Andrius KUBILIUS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, it’s a very important resolution, and I urge everybody to vote in favour. The issue which the resolution speaks about is crucial for the future of the whole European continent. That future will depend very much on when and how Russia will come back to being a democratic country which respects international law and human rights. For the time being this is not the case, and that is the reason why not only Ukraine and Georgia are suffering but Russians themselves are suffering very heavily also. We in Lithuania have a very special interest in having good relations with Russia, but that is possible only if and when Russia comes back to behaviour based on international law, democracy and human rights. How can we assist Russia? First of all, by speaking out very clearly about violations of international law and human rights and staying strong with sanctions and even looking for new instruments to influence the wrong behaviour of Russian authorities. It’s needed for Ukrainians, which are suffering aggression and being political prisoners. It’s needed for Russians themselves. It’s needed for the whole of Europe.

name: Sergey LAGODINSKY
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, dear colleagues, what would you say if your son or daughter did not come home one day? She went to a peaceful demonstration and never returned. What would you say if your brother or sister were declared a terrorist, just because they criticised a foreign country’s occupation? What would you say if your mother had to flee your country just because she was fighting for clean air with money from her European partners? These are sad stories that we hear from Russia. Stories of Sinaver Nimetullayev and six other Crimean Tatars, just recently jailed and detained on Red Square for peacefully protesting. Stories of Oleh Sentsov, Oleksandr Kolchenko, Oleksandr Shumkov and Volodymyr Balukh imprisoned for criticising Russia’s occupation of Crimea. Stories of Anastasia Shevchenko, who is under house arrest for months, just because her organisation was declared undesirable under the Russian statute. Some of you here talk about normalising relations with Russia. This resolution is our attempt to normalise relations with Russia. Not hiding behind gas pipes, not hiding behind fake observation missions to Crimea, but talking an honest conversation with Russia for the benefit of their citizens and citizens of Ukraine. This is our offer to this country. This is our offer to Moscow.  (Applause)

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This is, of course, a very important resolution and the ECR Group will support it. Indeed, since 2014, i.e. since the illegal annexation of Crimea and military aggression in eastern Ukraine, there have been many cases of human rights violations, disappearances, persecution and unlawful detention of Ukrainians and representatives of other minorities. That is why we support sanctions. On the other hand, I would like to draw attention to one point. We all know that many Member States tend to protect their own commercial interests in Russia rather than actually comply with sanctions. How, for example, is it possible that austrian oil company OMV agreed with Gazprom last month to buy back its stake in the Siberian gas fields for €900 million? How to explain that German direct investment in Russia in 2019 recorded a 33% increase compared to last year? There is therefore a need for greater consistency in the EU's policy towards Russia.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, this resolution is part of the escalation of confrontation promoted by the United States and NATO against the Russian Federation. An escalation of confrontation that includes the imposition of sanctions and which is part of the fascist coup d'état in Ukraine in 2014, with which the European Union has actively aligned. The resolution hides the policy of siege and warmongering that the United States and NATO have been developing against Russia, notably since 1999 with successive enlargements and the installation of military means at the borders of these countries. It is particularly serious and significant the whitewashing that the resolution makes of the Ukrainian regime and its policy of oppression and war against its own people of the violence of the action of Ukrainian fascist groups against Ukrainian populations. This situation brings more isolation, impoverishment and insecurity for the peoples of both regions, with consequences for other States. For example, as a result of the sanctions, pear producers in Portugal lose around EUR 250 million annually. A policy of peace and inclusion in a Europe of workers and peoples is an urgency of civilization.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – Dear President! When the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe returned Russia's right to vote, proponents of such a decision hoped that Russia would be more respectful of human rights, as well as release of Ukrainian imprisoned sailors and other political prisoners. Unfortunately, Russia has not only done so, but continues to intensify the repression. The so-called Duma elections in the Moscow city of Duma turned into mockery of democratic standards last weekend, and those who tried to protest against it were harshly repressed. Russia has demonstrated its environmental repressive culture in the case of the Astravo nuclear power plant, where Rusatom, despite protests from environmentalists and findings of violations of the ESPO Convention, is completing the construction of an unsafe power plant right at the border of the European Union. The European Union must use all possible sanctions against those russian representatives who violate human rights and persecute people, journalists and environmentalists.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, thank you so much for this opportunity to discuss the human-rights situation in Russia and, in particular, the situation of both illegally detained Ukrainians and environmental activists. The European Union has repeatedly expressed concern at the fate of all Ukrainian citizens illegally detained in the Crimean Peninsula and in Russia. These include Crimean Tatars and others who have opposed the illegal annexation as well as other Ukrainians. We continue to call for the immediate and unconditional release of the captured Ukrainian servicemen and their vessels, as has been ordered by the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea. Diplomats from the EU delegations in our Member States’ embassies in Moscow regularly attend the court hearings and are in constant contact with the lawyers. The European Union also regularly raises individual cases – including those of Oleg Sentsov, Pavlo Hryb and Edem Bekirov, who, as you know, require urgent medical assistance – in bilateral meetings with Russian representatives and in public statements, including in the Council of Europe and also in the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe. Russia holds special responsibility for respecting human rights in the illegally annexed Crimean Peninsula. The rights to legal counsel, access to consular officers and health care must be fully respected. The Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights has noted that Crimean Tatars continue to be disproportionately affected by police raids and prosecutions in respect of offences related to terrorism and extremism, in proceedings that fall short of human-rights standards. All pending cases of violations and abuses should be thoroughly investigated. The human-rights situation in non-government-controlled areas of eastern Ukraine, where Russia plays a significant role, is also deeply worrying. The overall environment for human-rights and civil-society activists in Russia is characterised by restriction on fundamental freedoms. At a time of international awareness of climate issues, violent assaults on individual environmental activists, such as Andrei Rudomakha and his colleagues, and the judicial harassment of others, such as the non—governmental organisation Eco-Defence, are deeply troubling. We recall that it is the duty of the Russian authorities to respect and protect the right of all illegally detained Ukrainian citizens and the rights of Russian citizens and activists, in line with Russia’s international human-rights commitments. I conclude by reaffirming our strong commitment to, and support for, human rights and civil society, including environmental activists in Russia, as well as illegally detained Ukrainians in particular. The European Union has consistently called on Russia to ensure that human-rights violations in Russia and the Crimean Peninsula are investigated and that accountability and justice for victims are ensured. Thank you for your attention.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The debate is closed. The vote will be held at the end of the debates. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – We are witnessing a long escalation of confrontation, promoted by the US and NATO and to which the EU has joined, against the Russian Federation. This escalation of confrontation includes the sanctions that the EU has successively renewed against this country. It also integrated, it is good not to forget, the fascist coup d'état in Ukraine in 2014.  The resolution hides the warlike policy of siege of Russia, which the US and NATO have been carrying out, notably since 1999, with successive enlargements of NATO and the installation of military resources along Russian borders.  The laundering of the Ukrainian regime and its policy of oppression and war against its own people, the violence and the action of Ukrainian fascist groups against Ukrainian populations has been particularly serious and significant.  This has a number of negative implications. More isolation, impoverishment and insecurity for peoples. On this path it is necessary to counter a policy of peace and inclusion.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. – This weekend, Ukrainian director and political prisoner Oleh Sencov celebrated his sixth birthday in a Russian prison. He and many other prisoners of conscience in Russia do not want to settle for Russia's occupation of Crimea, which began five years ago this year. But it didn't budze with the Russian regime. Even EU sanctions, however much we must insist on maintaining them, have not changed much. That is why we must take a more forceful stand against human rights violations in Russia. That is the position I expect from the new President of the Commission. As long as there are political prisoners in Russia and Russia does not respect international law, President Putin and his government are not a credible partner for us.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Madam President, just 20 seconds of colleagues’ time, because this is the last sitting. We’ve all just been elected as representatives of the people and legislators. For democracy it is essential that elected representatives can do their work freely and safely, and that applies to representatives around the world, including in the United States. I note that there are four members of the US Congress who have recently been subject to hate speech and intimidation and harassment, cheered on by nobody less than the President himself. Just last week, there was a rally that was addressed by President Trump himself... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Madam in 't Veld, may I just say, could you wind up? It isn’t quite a point of order but I don’t want to disrupt it. There are other speakers who want to come in. Gentlemen and ladies, could I ask you to show some respect? (Applause) You have the floor. And please listen with respect. Please listen.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Madam President, one representative in particular was targeted at a rally where President Trump spoke and they were chanting ‘Send her back’, because she has an immigration background. I think it is the duty of this House to condemn those attacks and express solidarity with those representatives. (Sustained applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: As I said, colleagues, it wasn’t quite a point of order. But we are at the... Calm down please. Madam Fox, you have a request?

name: Claire FOX
text: – Madam President, a question and point of order.  Is there a list of offensive banned words that can’t be used in this Parliament? As a new MEP, I ask this question because yesterday a colleague was reprimanded, indeed humiliated, for using the word ‘rubbish’ in his speech, which seemed rather disproportionate, especially when we have seen people wearing garments with far more offensive words. I ask this genuinely. Has this Parliament got a secret list? Because in the name of fairness and free speech, new MEPs like me need to get the ‘verboten’ word list, so we don’t make any more mistakes in the future. (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I know that there are more new Members then old in the House, and I think as one of the old ones, we’re flexible and we won’t get upset about words. However, I do admit that there was a former colleague here from the United Kingdom and we had a frank exchange of views when he would use the word ‘rubbish’ in just about all his sentences. So we will see if there is a list and we certainly will provide it, but to the best of my knowledge, I have not been provided with one. I think we all know as adults, though, when words are offensive, and perhaps if we use our own judgment that might be best. (Applause)

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I refer to Rule 39 of the Rules of Procedure, in which Parliament undertakes to ensure respect for human rights. Italian Interior Minister Matteo Salvini wants to re-energise the ethnic group of Gypsies living in Italy. This is contrary to the law. We all know whose instrument was this type of recording and what the objectives were. Salvini puts innocent people, women and children on the streets for the very reason of their ethnicity. I call on Parliament to take much stronger action against anti-Gypsyism and right-wing populists as Salvini is one of them, and to condemn them. This policy is an attack on European values and a disgrace to Europe. This is pure racism! (Applause and cries of protest)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Zanni, you'd like to respond, I'm sure.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is shameful that a Member of Parliament thinks that he is using the Rules of Procedure to attack a government legitimately elected by the Italian people. Shame!

name: Martin HORWOOD
text: – Madam President, on a point of order: we have some 500 new Members of the European Parliament for whom this is a new procedure and you are going much too fast. It’s almost too fast to press the buttons so we just need to pace it a little. (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Horwood is absolutely correct. I have been known to be quite fast on the button here, so you are absolutely right to stop me in my tracks. Out of respect for the new Members, I will now go at a more reasonable pace, and apologies if I caused any distress.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, exactly five years ago, Malaysia Airlines plane MH 17 was downed over the eastern part of Ukraine and 298 people vanished. It was an act of human brutality and a crime against humanity. An international investigation commission has established those who are in charge with the Russian military and equipment. There is nothing mentioned in this resolution, but colleagues, we can’t forget this crime and should bring those responsible to justice. (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Colleagues, I have an announcement to make. I am proposing that the provisions of Rule 202 be waived and that the minutes of yesterday’s sitting be approved here and now, and I am asking the Chamber if there any objections. As that is not the case, the minutes are approved, and I shall forward them with the resolutions adopted during this part-session to the persons and bodies named in the resolutions.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, honourable Members, I abstained from supporting this resolution because it has too many political definitions and too much side-taking. My firm belief is that neither the European Union nor the European Parliament should take extreme views and try to interfere in the internal affairs of sovereign states, particularly since before this resolution we voted on another one that concerned relations along the so-called American-Mexican border and the other resolution again included extreme comments, political assessments, an attempt to conduct a far-left policy on migration and illegal migrants , an attempt to justify illegal migration. I can't accept this kind of behavior or that kind of policy. I firmly believe that countries must negotiate at government level and make their decisions at government level. I think such resolutions do not help bilateral relations and do not work in the interests of citizens of the Member States of the European Union.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The session of the European Parliament is adjourned, our sitting is closed and I wish you all a very happy summer holidays. I look forward to seeing you back in the Chamber in September.
